subject: Geography
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course/subject?
"The highway toward understanding climate change stretches off into the distance...Our future will be much brighter if we can traverse this highway before we are overtaken by changing climate." States Richard B Alley in "The Two-Mile Time Machine". In this book, Alley discusses ice cores reflecting on abrupt climate changes in Earth's past and how to approach our climate-changing future. Alley highlights the global physical pump, a concept I had learnt in A-level geography. Alley explains particularly that the North Atlantic circulation pump is a powerful switch determining Earth's climate, namely, through the shutdown of the pump catalysed by Dansgaard-Oeschger events and Heinrich events. These events adversely alter climate dynamics by creating a drier climate in the Northern Hemisphere, disrupting monsoon circulation, expanding deserts, and shrinking tropical wetlands, thus reducing methane concentration in the atmosphere. Dansgaard-Oeschger events happen as a result of a warming climate, causing ice to melt and input large amounts of freshwater into the ocean. Heinrich events similarly produce the same consequence. This disrupts the delicate balance between saline and freshwater in the North Atlantic, which is necessary to operate the pump, effectively shutting down the North Atlantic circulation. With a warming climate and increased ice melting, I now question whether anthropogenic means can induce these events and what this means for our climate.
With climate change, I understand the importance of recognising the human aspects that enable this damage. Accordingly, I read "This Changes Everything" by Naomi Klein. This book offers a broad perspective on the long-standing conflict between humans and the environment, mixing geopolitics, science, economics and behavioural sciences. Klein emphasises how environmental injustices suffered by indigenous and marginalised communities expose societal flaws. She controversially frames geoengineering as a "fix it later approach", further prompting me to understand that science should not be a way to mask the failures of our current approaches to climate change as societies, or to mess with natural systems that we have yet to grasp fully, but rather as a way to demand substantial change. Ultimately, Klein inspires by challenging capitalist rules and redefining the climate crisis not just as a threat, but as a striking opportunity to confront our inherently flawed societies and rebuild them. This course intrigues me with the wealth of scientific knowledge it offers in its modules and its contribution to insightful and unique perspectives on tackling climate change. Studying this course marks the beginning of my involvement in the change I long for: driving our societies towards sustainable growth, developing solutions to mitigate the effects of climate change, and, most importantly, helping to reduce the number of "losers" in this climate challenge. This course distinctively offers me the chance to explore our relationship with Earth and how to improve this relationship, echoing the words of Ted Nield in "Supercontinent": "Until we can live without her, Earth is not a part of our story - we are a part of hers.".

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this subject?
In biology, I have learnt about the processes of photosynthesis and respiration and their importance in plants, especially. These processes have been further contextualised in geography through the study of case studies of the Amazon Rainforest and the Arctic Tundra, which emphasise the role of plants in the carbon cycle, one of Earth's life support systems. This further piqued my interest in understanding the role of plants in regulating the climate, leading me to read "The Emerald Planet" by David Beerling. Beerling illustrates the evolutionary journey of plants from the Palaeozoic era to the Cenozoic era. What stood out to me the most was Beerling's continual reinforcement of feedback processes throughout the book. He illustrates how, since the beginning of time, our climate has been powered by feedback responses. Although we cannot be certain precisely what feedback processes took place, we know how influential these processes are, from causing mass extinctions to providing a set of Goldilocks conditions for life. It is precisely the uncertainty of which way feedback processes could favour that is terrifying about anthropogenic climate change. However, Beerling does not end the book on that note; he reminds us that, from period to period, life has persisted through climatic changes. It does not eliminate the costs that climate change will demand from us, nor the need to address it, but at least it offers hope for humanity in the face of climate change.

What have you done to prepare outside of education and why were these experiences useful?
I have participated in two of Immerse Education's essay-based offers, an essay competition and an online research program. The essay I produced for the competition was titled "Evaluating the Impact of Human Activity on the Earth's Geology". I first examined the Anthropocene, discussing its definition and legitimacy as a formally recognised epoch. To demonstrate anthropogenic impacts, I highlighted mining as a cause of sinkholes, fracking-triggered earthquakes, and the presence of radioactive isotopes in isolated sinkhole lakes. My evaluation concluded that the lasting impact of human activity on Earth's geology remains heavily debatable and unclear. Furthermore, I understood that the examples I had researched were merely scratching the surface of such a multifaceted topic. I concluded that with continual technological advances, humans may soon be able to leave a lasting mark on geology that will endure through time. For my research program, I developed the title "Is the UK on Track to Fulfil Its Climate Commitments Under the Paris Agreement? An Analysis of the UK's 2030 NDC and Carbon Budgets" to focus on the human side of climate change, an area that challenges me. This topic proved demanding, but my findings were fruitful. I found that to meet the targeted emissions savings outlined in the Paris Agreement, there is a need to make electricity cheaper, specifically by making it cheaper than natural gas. This acts as an incentive for the adoption of low-carbon technologies, including heat pumps and electric cars. Furthermore, helping the UK address the necessary emissions savings in the energy supply, buildings and surface transport sectors. With one area experiencing a drop in emissions, a domino effect will ensue, triggering reductions in the other two areas. Cheaper electricity will support nationwide electrification, decarbonising the entirety of the UK.
My leadership in the Environmental Society at school has been immensely rewarding. A key highlight was delivering a talk on AI and climate change, where I discussed my findings on the carbon footprint of AI and its applications in combating climate change, including reforestation projects, recycling systems, and ocean cleanup. I was challenged by younger years, who posed questions like, "If AI can be used to combat climate change, why has its use in this area still been so limited?" Prompting me to reflect on my superficial understanding of AI. Before this speech, I failed to recognise that AI is not just generative; ChatGPT. Controversially, I concluded that, given the current generative AI boom, other forms of AI, such as those used to combat climate change, are not a priority area for investment. However, its future possibilities are vast, indicating a greater need for scientific knowledge to be applied in this sector. The study of Environmental science is crucial in this age of AI, for steering AI towards being a sword for climate justice rather than destruction.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Your writing in general needs cleaning up - too many clauses in a sentence, very unclear. Some sentences are miles long and it's very difficult to understand the point. It doesn't read super nicely. You have to split up independent clauses properly.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Always start with concise sentences. Think: what is the most basic idea? Put that into the shortest, most complete sentence possible. Then think what supporting points you need and bring in more clauses. Don't just start a sentence and end it where you like. Start shorter and then add.

feedback_items.weak_passage: prompting me to reflect on my superficial understanding of AI. Before the speech, I failed to recognise that AI is not just generative; ChatGPT
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's not how you use a semicolon. You have to split up independent clauses. The sentence about 'controversially, I concluded that, given the current generative AI boom' is really not grammatically good either.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Fix semicolon usage and clean up sentence structure throughout

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall, this doesn't read like a personal statement. It reads like a set of notes for a longer essay. It's not critical enough, it's much more of a summary.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: You need 3 strong sections - pick clear, differentiated modules from what you're studying. Make each section complete: thesis development, went on to do something further, conclusion learned from there, explained something you already knew and extended, then contrasting with something that needs further exploration.

feedback_items.weak_passage: "The highway toward understanding climate change stretches off into the distance...Our future will be much brighter if we can traverse this highway before we are overtaken by changing climate."
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't include a quotation. It's way too long, such a waste of space, and it doesn't really tell me about your understanding of something.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the quotation and start directly with your analysis

feedback_items.weak_passage: In this book, Ali discusses ice cores reflecting on abrupt climate changes and Earth's past and how to approach our climate changing future. Alley highlights the global physical pump concept I had learned in A Level geography, explains the North Atlantic circulation pump is a powerful switch determining Earth's climate
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just a summary. You summarize the book for several sentences - all of that could have been condensed. What would have been better is if you said what his actual conclusion was - 'Ali posits that we should approach climate change by [conclusion]'. Then pick ONE interesting concept like the North Atlantic circulation pump instead of listing 12 examples.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense to: Ali's conclusion, one interesting concept (North Atlantic pump), a couple of examples max, then expand on 'I started to question whether anthropogenic means can induce these events' by linking to a recent article. Show the link between: read and pulled out conclusion/main point, linked to what's happening today, looking at another theory to contrast.

feedback_items.weak_passage: These events adversely alter climate dynamics by creating a drier climate in the Northern Hemisphere, disrupting monsoon circulation, expanding deserts, and shrinking tropical wetlands, thus reducing methane concentration in the atmosphere.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't need that many examples - you've given like 12. Give a couple of examples instead.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reduce to 2-3 key examples maximum

feedback_items.your_feedback: That entire section right now is just like a set of notes from that book, and it's not showing the link between: I've read and I've pulled out this conclusion/main point, I've linked it to what's happening today, I am looking at this other theory to contrast. I'm not really learning anything about you and the way that you think and understand something.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Follow the model: thesis point → specific conclusion from source → development into depth of theory → contrast with own prior knowledge → link to something relevant in the field → example showing true understanding. Make it 4-5 sentences total for a complete section.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Your topics are kind of samey - they're not clearly differentiated. Because you're doing geography and geology and kind of a mix of things, it's a little bit directionless.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Go onto your course page, look at year 1 core modules or optional modules in year 2-3, and shape your statement through those modules. That's the cleanest, clearest way to do it because that's how you learn and it's familiar to tutors.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Nothing you've done is bad. You don't need to do a lot more. It's literally just about restructuring, reshaping so it sounds more like a statement, and then rewriting so that your writing is a bit cleaner.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Restructure using the complete section model shown in the feedback. Clean up grammar and sentence structure throughout. Differentiate sections more clearly.

subject: Psychology
statement_full_text:
The potential relationship between childhood trauma and later violence - the idea of a 'downstream wreckage' - fascinates me, where initially I had assumed that adverse experiences in childhood e.g. repeated verbal or physical abuse from emotionally unpredictable and substance-dependant parents have always led to later interpersonal problems. However, by listening to the podcast of 'Does trauma cause violence?' by the Reith lectures, it has prompted me to question the extent to which this is a causal relationship. What intrigued me was the notion that within the same hostile and dysfunctional environment, siblings can have drastically different outcomes with one going on to potentially becoming a violent perpetrator and one leading a normal life. From this I began to reflect on the variability in human responses to stressors and how such differences play out in real life clinical settings, which naturally led me to explore the theme further in psychopathology – in particular the limitations of diagnostic criteria in relation to the DSM.
This curiosity prompted me on to read the book 'Madness Explained: Psychosis and Human Nature' by Richard P. Bentall, whose critique of traditional diagnostic systems such as the DSM compelled me to reflect on how, despite continued revisions throughout the years, they often neglect the interplay between individual histories and external circumstances. This led me to consider a key finding from the ECA study highlighted in the book, which found that over half of patients with a psychiatric disorder met criteria for at least one other disorder. This prompted me to question the assumption that mental disorders exist as discrete categories, and how such a rigid diagnostic approach ineffectively leads to treatments centred on the disorders rather than the person holistically.
To broaden my knowledge on the different perspectives of psychiatric diagnoses, I engaged with reading Rosenhan's study On Being Sane in Insane Places, and was particularly fascinated by its exploration on the boundaries of sanity and insanity. It enabled me to reflect on whether a specific environment i.e. a psychiatric hospital is crucial in determining how an individual is perceived to be sane or insane. The fact that the 'normal' behaviours were interpreted as manifestations of a certain disturbance merely due to a psychiatric setting redefined my view on how powerful labels are. Through Rosenhan's study, I came to recognise the lasting impacts of psychodiagnostics labels e.g. 'schizophrenic' 'insane' 'manic-depressive' at both personal and social levels ,which I found to be deeply unsettling. Such labels, whether accurate or not, can become permanently ingrained, which can depersonalise individuals and even turn into a self-fulfilling prophecy. However, when I later watched Louis Theroux's documentary By Reason of Insanity, I realised that labels may not be… The documentary directed my attention towards the experiences of mentally ill patients within the legal system, and what stood out to me was that some mentally disordered offenders, detained for treatment in a psychiatric facility under NGRI, expressed preference for retaining the label of 'mentally ill' instead of facing standard procedures. This prompted me to reconsider how psychiatric labels can be both constraining and protective, depending on the individual's context and interpretation.
Reflecting on society broad perceptions of mental health sparked my curiosity in how the brain's specific functions shape behaviour at a structural level.Initially, I assumed that individuals in a vegetative state would be unresponsive to external cues. However after watching Adrian Owen's TEDTalk The Quest for Consciousness, I was struck by evidence from fMRIs showing that some patients retained conscious awareness and were able to perform deliberate actions in the premotor cortex. This made me realise how significant brain functions are in underpinning surface behaviour. Similarly, I found Nadine Burke Harris' talk interesting regarding how early adversity shapes brain development structurally and functionally, affecting areas such as the nucleus accumbens.
I conducted an independent research project exploring the association between attachment types and conflict styles, which involved designing my own questionnaire and analysing large data sets – an experience that strengthened my research and analytical skills essential for studying psychology at university. As a maths mentor and literacy volunteer, I fostered positive learning environments collaboratively whilst developing leadership and communication skills. Being a psychology prefect allowed me to share my passion by organizing a lunchtime club. Furthermore, I am a Grade 8 pianist which reflects my dedication and discipline – qualities that will prove invaluable in research and clinical settings.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I think it's genuinely very well done. The sections are really interesting and you've included a good number of sources and references. You've done a lot of really interesting things.
feedback_items.why_strong: Really well done overall, interesting sections, good number of sources and references, did really well at GCSE with 3 A stars

feedback_items.your_feedback: Some sources are a little bit less academic than you'd really want them to be - they're for general public interest as opposed to academic interests. You've got TED Talks, documentaries, and things like this which are for the everyday person.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you've read anything slightly beyond what you've included, add an academic paper at the end. Look at the course page, find admissions tutors who will be teaching you, look at the type of papers they've published, and include something at that level. This would show understanding of university level papers.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You haven't included a longer essay, which is pretty standard at this point. You have an independent research project but don't go into enough detail about it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand significantly on your independent research project about attachment styles, or include details about another substantial essay you've written

feedback_items.weak_passage: The potential relationship between childhood trauma and later violence - the idea of a 'downstream wreckage' - fascinates me, where initially I had assumed that adverse experiences in childhood e.g. repeated verbal or physical abuse from emotionally unpredictable and substance-dependant parents have always led to later interpersonal problems.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The first couple of sentences are really confusing and don't read very well. Where did you find the relationship between childhood trauma and violence? You should link that and say 'according to X study'. The 'e.g.' about abuse doesn't add a whole lot - it's not the interesting part. It's confusing which part you're surprised by because you seem to be saying the same thing twice.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rephrase to: cite a specific study about trauma-violence link, remove the 'e.g.' detail, clarify what assumption you're contrasting. Try: 'A podcast by [name] prompted me to question [specific thing]' - take out 'however' which is causing confusion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: What intrigued me was the notion that within the same hostile and dysfunctional environment, siblings can have drastically different outcomes with one going on to potentially become a violent perpetrator and one leading a normal life.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Your writing style in general is not always the most clear and concise. That sentence is not a very clean sentence structure. Phrasing like 'what intrigued me' - you do this throughout. If you could clean up the writing a little bit, it would help tutors who are scanning for 5 minutes and looking for red flags or anything particularly interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Take a critical look at your writing. Make it easy reading - tutors shouldn't have to go back and reread. With yours, I have to read and then go back because of the writing style.

feedback_items.weak_passage: From this I began to reflect on the variability in human responses to stressors and how such differences play out in real life clinical settings
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is fine but quite general and not very specific. You don't say what kind of variability, what kind of responses, what kind of stresses. It's like saying 'I started to think about numbers' - yes, but so what should I take from that? 'How such differences play out in real life clinical settings' is like saying 'and I thought about it' with no conclusions or development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be specific about what variability, which responses, which stresses. Draw a conclusion or show development rather than just stating you reflected.

feedback_items.weak_passage: As a maths mentor and literacy volunteer, I fostered positive learning environments collaboratively whilst developing leadership and communication skills. Being a psychology prefect allowed me to share my passion by organizing a lunchtime club.
feedback_items.your_feedback: If that's an in-school thing, I would prefer that to be in the reference just because you've got a lot of other good things going on. The teacher reference is 4000 characters so there's a lot of space - nobody really fills up that space otherwise.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move in-school activities like maths mentor, literacy volunteer, and psychology prefect to the teacher reference to save space for academic content

feedback_items.your_feedback: It's kind of similar issues throughout with unclear writing and vague conclusions. But you've done a very good job though, still. You've clearly done this yourself, I can clearly tell you've done a proper journey through. For Oxford, this is fine - they care less about the statement than you'd think. They care more about admissions exams and other things.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you cleaned up the writing and included some higher level academic sources, you should probably be OK. Don't worry too much if you want to leave it as is, because it's also not bad.

subject: PPE
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?
I am driven by a conviction that rising conflict, inequality and polarisation around the world is drawing us towards Arendt's "banality of evil", and moreover that PPE is uniquely suited to help me challenge this.
I concurred with Frankfurt's "On Bullshit", that a societal disregard for truth undermines both our discourse and economic agency. To expand on this, I participated in the NEULondon essay competition on the causes of political polarisation, arguing the perverse structural incentives of social media penalise integrity exemplified by the phenomenon of Frankfurtian bullshit in "memes" used as ironic rhetorical tools, for which I received a distinction. Applying Mill's "free market of ideas" framework, I ultimately concluded that the information landscape is skewed towards extreme viewpoints. However, I disagreed with Chomsky's view that economic elites collude to "manufacture consent", instead, I believe polarisation in our media is rising precisely because there is no centre of control.
To what extent does imperfect information cause war? Mostly, I decided, after encountering the concept of ESSs presented by Dawkins, drawing heavily from Game Theory, as a model for intrastate behaviour. I applied this framework to the Ukraine War, where, despite incurring costs by continuing to fight, bargaining frictions caused by imperfect information (as both sides' ability to fight is contingent on unpredictable factors such as foreign aid) elude solution. My view was challenged in "Notes From the Underground" where Dostoevsky attacks assumptions of human rationality, which led me to question the central assumptions of neoclassical economics and game theory. Could wars be caused by emotions, 'great men' or cultural history? Dostoevsky's view that over-rationalising our decisions dishonestly distances ourselves from our morality to me highlights the dangers of the "banality of evil" ever-present in our politics.

How have your qualifications or studies prepared you to study this subject?
In A-Level history, my teacher introduced me to the fascinating concept of "Napoleon's dictum", which argues that a person can be understood through the lens of the world when they were 20. I related this to notions of whether our wills can ever truly be "free" if they are so strongly influenced by the environment, a view I encountered from Robert Sapolsky on the 'Within Reason' podcast. In my interpretation of "The Stranger", the moral and psychological control society seeks to impose on Meursault through his trial struck me as another example of social determinism. Moreover, this has led me to question whether freedom is paradoxical in a determinist universe: non-random events must be determined, but neither collapsing into pure randomness nor pure determinism seem to bring about freedom.

What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and how have these experiences been useful?
What is the best way to develop a poor country? I initially agreed with Acemoglu/Robinson's central thesis that inclusive institutions (such as those found in the settler-colonial structure of the US compared to quasi-feudal colonial México) are conducive to economic growth, which I found built of off Smith's initial observation that merchants and businessmen would try to rig markets in their favour. Building on this, I wrote in the student publication Etonomics and argued in "Great Expectations and the Indian economy that never was" that extractive institutions (such as the License Raj in India) are immoral because they perpetuated unequal economic control, exercised through elite networks and entrenched underdevelopment. Amartya Sen's humanist capabilities-led approach took a similar approach to criticising political and economic unfreedoms; I found his argument for redefining development in terms of substantive freedoms compelling.
Leading my school's MUN and philosophy societies, I researched democratic backsliding around the world. Learning about crackdowns on judicial independence, the separation of powers and military coups in sub-Saharan Africa affirmed my belief in the intrinsic value of democracy. Choosing this as a tutorial topic during Balliol College's Floreat programme, I wrote an essay about the causes of democratisation and participated in a small-group discussion.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Still quite a few issues. Primarily, you're just jumping around way too much still - lots of name dropping, underdeveloped theories. Some of the theories don't play that well together.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop theories more fully and ensure they connect logically rather than just name-dropping

feedback_items.weak_passage: I am convinced that rising levels of conflict, inequality, and the polarisation of ???? → as seen in??? or in the case of? globally draws us closer towards Arendt's "banality of evil"
feedback_items.your_feedback: Rising levels of conflict, inequality, and polarisation - needs specific examples. Say 'as seen in' or 'in the case of' with concrete instances.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add: 'as seen in [specific examples]' and clarify that PPE helps you 'understand/analyse this growing problem'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I concurred with Frankfurt's "On Bullshit", that a societal disregard for truth undermines both our discourse and economic agency.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Discourse surrounding what? About what? Economic agency with regards to what? These need to be specified.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify: 'discourse surrounding [specific topic]' and 'economic agency with regards to [specific area]'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I found that structural incentives such as ? caused people to ?…... Applying Mill's "free market of ideas" framework to ???, I found that x showed the information landscape is skewed towards extreme viewpoints.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to explain: structural incentives such as WHAT caused people to do WHAT. Applying Mill's framework to WHAT specifically. Need bridging sentences where theories have been name-dropped in.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Fill in all gaps - specify what structural incentives, what they caused, what you applied Mill's framework to, and what x was that showed the skewing

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, I disagreed with Chomsky's view that economic elites collude to "manufacture consent", instead, I believe polarisation of ? in our media is rising
feedback_items.your_feedback: Polarisation of what in our media?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify what aspect of media is experiencing polarisation

feedback_items.weak_passage: To what extent does imperfect information cause war? Mostly, I decided, after encountering the concept of ESSs presented by Dawkins, drawing heavily from Game Theory, as a model for intrastate behaviour
feedback_items.your_feedback: This doesn't really make sense - it will sound like you haven't read the book properly. Better: 'I studied Dawkin's concept of ESSs and found the Hawk-Dove result particularly interesting' - something along these lines is better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reframe to show proper understanding of Dawkins' concept rather than vague reference

feedback_items.weak_passage: I applied this framework to the Ukraine War, where, despite incurring costs by continuing to fight, bargaining frictions caused by imperfect information
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not the best idea to apply game theory to real-life case of war. Game theory really works best where you can play repeated games and there aren't other factors affecting outcomes.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change to more 'in theory' language rather than claiming this explains an ongoing conflict

feedback_items.weak_passage: My view was challenged in "Notes From the Underground" where Dostoevsky attacks assumptions of human rationality, which led me to question the central assumptions of neoclassical economics and game theory.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The central assumptions being what? You need to specify.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add: 'The central assumptions being [specify which assumptions]'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I related this to notions of whether our wills can ever truly be "free" if they are so strongly influenced by the environment such as x, y, z, a view I encountered from Robert Sapolsky
feedback_items.your_feedback: Environment such as x, y, z - you need to give examples. What specific environmental factors?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Specify which environmental factors influence free will

feedback_items.weak_passage: a view I encountered from Robert Sapolsky on the 'Within Reason' podcast. In my interpretation of "The Stranger"
feedback_items.your_feedback: Jumps too quick - no link/development between Sapolsky and The Stranger. You need bridging content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add sentence connecting Sapolsky's podcast discussion to how this influenced your interpretation of The Stranger. Show the intellectual journey.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I initially agreed with Acemoglu and Robinson's central thesis that inclusive institutions, such as those found in the settler-colonial structure of the US compared to quasi-feudal colonial México, are the most effective way to drive development; I found this built of off Smith's initial observation
feedback_items.your_feedback: Over simplifying relationship between US and Mexico - also did they not literally colonise i.e. not inclusive! Not the best knowledge - Smith and Acemoglu arguments are fundamentally arguing different things.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reconsider this comparison - the US example isn't truly 'inclusive' given colonization. Also, Smith and Acemoglu are making fundamentally different arguments so this connection doesn't work well.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Building on this, I wrote in the student publication Etonomics and argued in "Great Expectations and the Indian economy that never was" that extractive institutions (such as the License Raj in India) are immoral
feedback_items.your_feedback: This led to what? You need to show what conclusion or next step came from this argument.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add: 'This led to [explain next intellectual step or conclusion]'

feedback_items.weak_passage: Amartya Sen's humanist capabilities-led approach took a similar approach to criticising political and economic unfreedoms; I found his argument for redefining development in terms of substantive freedoms compelling.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is because what? Why did you find it compelling? You need to explain.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add: 'This is because [explain why you found Sen's argument compelling]'

feedback_items.your_feedback: One of the biggest areas that is a bit problematic is the game theory section, and also the Acemoglu-Smith connection.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Review and revise the game theory application to Ukraine and the Smith-Acemoglu connection - these need significant work

subject: Natural Sciences
statement_full_text:
Q1:

My decision to study natural sciences stems from a fascination with how biology, chemistry and physics intersect to explain fundamental questions. I delved into this by reading Tim Coulson's 'The Universal History of Us' in which he demonstrates the crucial need to understand these interactions, particularly in how life emerged from non-living matter through a series of chemical and physical processes.

I have attended multiple Cambridge Natural Sciences taster days, where I found the course structure to be ideal as I wish to explore science broadly while eventually specialising. At one, we were given a talk on how to study evolution using the hydrostatics of blood flow. This demonstrated the flexibility of the course, allowing students to explore across the traditional subject boundaries. It also revealed to me the importance of a multidisciplinary scientific approach, particularly in research. Furthermore, reading about pioneering cellular treatments such as T cell editing in Mukherjee's 'The Song of the Cell' made me think of a career in pharmaceutical research. I would love to be involved at the cutting edge of new discoveries to have a positive impact, and it is clear that studying natural sciences offers the best foundation for this.

Q2

Through both biological and physical sciences extension programmes, I have developed my research skills and explored new areas of science, such as biomaterials. I investigated bone-regenerating hydrogels, which led me to Wedlich's 'Slime: a Natural History'. Learning how the physical properties of hydrogels give them the remarkable ability to mimic the strength, flexibility and healing abilities of human skin made me appreciate how materials science and biology can combine in unexpected, innovative ways.
My problem-solving skills and understanding of core principles within science were developed by the Intermediate Biology Olympiad and Cambridge Chemistry Challenge. I achieved silver in both. I also took the initiative in forming a team for the Cambridge Biology Challenge, which developed critical thinking and collaborative skills by tackling complex problems such as 'does behaviour fossilize?'. In the two rounds we participated in, we won a distinction and highly commended.

Q3

Reading Bowater's 'The Microbes Fight Back' showed me that industrial antibiotic leakage is a greater cause of antibiotic resistance than human misuse, highlighting the urgent need for global cooperation and communication. This inspired my research proposal, through St John's Oxford Inspire programme, on whether mRNA vaccines are the future of vaccination. Currently, due to their instability, mRNA vaccines require ultra-cold storage, severely limiting their global usage. I explored how recent innovations like lyophilisation and circular mRNA may overcome this instability and increase mRNA vaccine accessibility. The project gave me experience of engaging with academic research papers, providing exposure to university level study. I was awarded a research project award, which included a research skills day and a £100 book voucher.

I spent a week shadowing scientists in the Raff Lab at the Dunn School of Pathology, learning how molecular biology experiments are carried out and analysed. I realised the persistence research demands and how techniques like fluorescent imaging rely on physics and chemistry. This built on earlier experience at the Biomedical Imaging Unit at Southampton General Hospital, where I observed advanced microscopy techniques in a healthcare setting. At the NHR Clinical Research Facility lab, I gained practical experience by independently processing a fake sample. I followed manuals and documentation, best practices and used equipment, developing time-management and lab skills essential in a demanding and scientific course like natural sciences.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My decision to study natural sciences stems from a fascination with how biology, chemistry and physics intersect to explain fundamental questions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole first sentence is not good. I would just remove that. It says absolutely nothing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete the first sentence and start with: 'I read Tim Coulson's Universal History and this explained the need to understand the interactions between biology, chemistry, and physics in order to see [continue with rest]'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I have attended multiple natural science days where I found the course structure to be ideal, as I wish to explore science broadly.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's not great - you focus too much on the flexibility of the course rather than something academic. Better to rephrase and talk more about the actual content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of 'this demonstrated the flexibility', say 'at Cambridge Natural Science day, we were given a talk on the study of evolution using the hydrostatics of blood flow. What I found interesting from this talk was [explain what was interesting]'

feedback_items.weak_passage: It also revealed to me the importance of a multidisciplinary scientific approach, particularly in research.
feedback_items.your_feedback: How did it reveal it? You don't actually say, so we're just supposed to agree and assume that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain HOW the talk revealed the importance of multidisciplinary approaches

feedback_items.weak_passage: Furthermore, reading about pioneering cellular treatments such as this made me think of a career in pharmaceutical research. I would love to be involved at the cutting edge of new discoveries to have a positive impact
feedback_items.your_feedback: Maybe instead of pharmaceutical research, don't link it to career. It's better to link it to something that's interesting academically - why was that interesting for you? Cut that last sentence about being at the cutting edge - it's not ideal.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace career discussion with academic interest. Delete the 'I'd love to be involved' sentence entirely.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Through both these programmes, I've developed research skills and things.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You guys do this so much, but don't - you don't need to say that. If you've done programmes, they know you have research skills. They know you have explored new areas of science, because by nature of completing the programmes, you will have. It's just a waste of space.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Don't say it. Just go straight into it: 'At a biological and physical science extension programme, I investigated [go straight into the Hydrogel stuff]'

feedback_items.your_feedback: The Hydrogel stuff sounds good, it's interesting, you make your point well. Maybe you could expand that a little bit more and talk about the limitations of hydrogels, what's going on in the future, maybe linking something from recent studies, maybe some alternatives.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand with: limitations of hydrogels, future research directions, recent studies, or alternatives
feedback_items.strong_passage: I investigated bone-regenerating hydrogels, which led me to Wedlich's 'Slime: a Natural History'. Learning how the physical properties of hydrogels give them the remarkable ability to mimic the strength, flexibility and healing abilities of human skin made me appreciate how materials science and biology can combine in unexpected, innovative ways.
feedback_items.why_strong: Good topic, sounds interesting, makes the point well

feedback_items.weak_passage: My problem-solving skills and understanding of core principles within science were developed by the Intermediate Biology Olympiad and Cambridge Chemistry Challenge. I achieved silver in both.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Obviously you developed problem solving skills and understanding - you don't need to say that. Better to go on the reference, or if not, just put it at the end really quickly just saying 'I also completed this and I won a silver'.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move to reference or condense to one quick sentence at the end

feedback_items.weak_passage: I also took the initiative in forming a team for the Cambridge Biology Challenge, which developed critical thinking and collaborative skills by tackling complex problems such as 'does behaviour fossilize?'.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's interesting. Don't say you develop critical thinking and collaborative skills. You mentioned the problem - why don't you just tell me what the answer was, how you solved it, tell me the methodology. That sounds very interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Skip the skills statement and explain: How did you solve 'does behaviour fossilize'? What was your answer? What methodology did you use?
feedback_items.why_strong: The Cambridge Biology Challenge formation shows initiative and the problem is interesting

feedback_items.weak_passage: In the two rounds we participated in, we won a distinction and highly commended.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't need to mention the rounds thing. If you can get it into your reference, that would just be much better. That gives you time to explore more of the theory side of stuff.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move awards mention to reference to create space for theory

feedback_items.your_feedback: That part was pretty good actually. I just wanted to know the conclusion of your essay - did you agree? Yes, it can be done, no it can't be done. I don't think you said.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add your conclusion: state whether you think mRNA vaccines are the future of vaccination based on your research
feedback_items.strong_passage: Reading Bowater's 'The Microbes Fight Back' showed me that industrial antibiotic leakage is a greater cause of antibiotic resistance than human misuse, highlighting the urgent need for global cooperation and communication. This inspired my research proposal, through St John's Oxford Inspire programme, on whether mRNA vaccines are the future of vaccination.
feedback_items.why_strong: Pretty good section, interesting research topic

feedback_items.weak_passage: The project gave me experience of engaging with academic research papers, providing exposure to university level study. I was awarded a research project award, which included a research skills day and a £100 book voucher.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is the same thing - you don't need to say that. Just remove that. The project award and voucher stuff is fine but not necessary - just move that to the front and say 'I've received an award for my research and conclusion that [add conclusion]' - that would be a nice complete paragraph.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Delete the 'gave me experience' sentence. Move award mention to start and integrate with your conclusion.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I realised the persistence research demands and how techniques like fluorescent imaging rely on physics and chemistry.
feedback_items.your_feedback: That's pretty obvious. Not the smartest conclusion to draw. Maybe you could mention something else - something else that you saw that you think is interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace with a more sophisticated observation from your shadowing experience

feedback_items.weak_passage: This built on earlier experience at the Biomedical Imaging Unit at Southampton General Hospital, where I observed advanced microscopy techniques in a healthcare setting. At the NHR Clinical Research Facility lab, I gained practical experience by independently processing a fake sample. I followed manuals and documentation, best practices and used equipment
feedback_items.your_feedback: You mentioned two more work experiences, but unless you're gonna bring out something interesting, it's kind of pointless. You gained practical experience processing a fake sample, followed manuals - that's a list of things. Maybe go into the fake sample thing more and say 'we did this and then this and then this', just to show you've actually done it and learned something, or maybe something you had to be careful of. But as it stands, that's just a list of traits that are necessary but kind of obvious.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either develop the fake sample processing in detail (step by step what you did, what you learned, what you had to be careful of) OR cut these experiences if you can't make them academically interesting

feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't know if that was a little bit harsh, but I think you have a really good base, really good ideas, excellent topics and things that you've done. I just think those little fixes would just make the whole thing a lot stronger. Take it, leave it as it is - it's also fine. Don't worry too much. But if you've got the time, why not?
feedback_items.why_strong: Really good base, really good ideas, excellent topics and things done

subject: Engineering (Mechanical)
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?

How do formula one cars stay on track while maintaining speed in turns? What enables planes to fly? How to bring ideas to reality? I have always been passionate about problem thinking and questioned the 'why' and the 'how' of things. However, my vocation for engineering became apparent after watching the movie 'cars', which interested me in Formula One. Through this sport, I fueled my interest in the field of fluid dynamics which ultimately led me to discover mechanical engineering – where design meets physics to solve real life problems. Through this I understood that engineering is everything around us, contributing to building the world we live in today. Boats are able to move with just the sheer force of the wind on the sail and the keel, bridges are able to carry impressive weights and hold up with just a few pillars, even something as basic as a paper clip are created by engineers. Our future is partly in the hands of engineers, and I would like to be part of this world, working towards real life problems such as climate change.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?

Through the subjects I studied, more specifically the notion of resultant forces such as lift and the stability of an object if it has low centers of mass and a wide base area, I was able to understand part of the Formula One cars design when it came to aerodynamics. However, to fully grasp the concept I read the article ' Aerodynamics designs in Formula One cars' by Tianyu Li . I was particularly struck by the way the rear wing creates 20 % of the downforce. With the design of the airfoil slightly angled, the air passing underneath flows much faster than that on top. In addition, according to Bernoulli's effect and the equation P + ½ ρv^^2 = constant, the slower the velocity of the flow, the higher the pressure is. Thus, the air pressure exerted on the airfoil pushes the air upwards and an opposing force pushes the car downwards creating downforce. Gaining knowledge on the way the air moves around a car, I saw a link between racing cars and planes, which used the same principle only the other way round. This led me to watch the Ted ED 'Why do wings help you fly?', which actually corrected a misconception of mine, the air divided by the wing does not ensemble back together after. It is the deflection of the wing and the slower velocity of the flow underneath the surface that pushes the plane upwards and slightly backwards creating both drag and lift.

Preparing for a French national logic Competition in which I finished in the top 1% , also helped me reinforce my critical and abstract thinking skills which are considered crucial qualities according to Guru Madhavan.

What else have you done to prepare outside of education,and why are these experiences useful?

To widen my knowledge of the engineering field, I read 'Think like an engineer' which outlines the engineering mind-set while designing a product. It claims that it is a 'modular systems thinking' where multiple techniques and principals mix to understand the flow of life. While visiting the Google labs center in Paris, I got to make links with the process described in the previous book, the way they made multiple prototypes and encouraged feedback to improve their projects and how they used different technologies in less developed countries to solve life-changing issues. Furthermore, experiencing work experience at Thales and IDEMIA - for which I followed the process of creation of a military surveillance radar as well as biometric systems of recognition used by the FBI, the Interpol and all main security systems -, I was struck by the importance of innovation. I was particularly fascinated by the constant change in products and small upgrades made on radars.This led me to read 'Where goods ideas come from: The natural history of innovation' by Steve Johnson. The author explains the concept of liquid networks, he claimed that innovations work like neurons, in a group where hunches and ideas can merge, all this balanced between chaos and order. This helps me understand the importance of group projects to which I look forward to participating in when I am studying at university.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Your only really academic paragraph is the middle one. But the problem is, these days, for some reason, all of you guys applying for engineering are talking about Formula One. Half of you are talking about Bernoulli's effect. I don't know if you've all watched the same documentary. You will be unfavourably compared - I've seen others do it at a higher level.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider choosing a different topic than Formula One and Bernoulli's effect, as this is extremely common among engineering applicants this year. If you keep it, push it to a much higher academic level.

feedback_items.weak_passage: How do formula one cars stay on track while maintaining speed in turns? What enables planes to fly? How to bring ideas to reality? I have always been passionate about problem thinking and questioned the 'why' and the 'how' of things. However, my vocation for engineering became apparent after watching the movie 'cars', which interested me in Formula One. Through this sport, I fueled my interest in the field of fluid dynamics which ultimately led me to discover mechanical engineering – where design meets physics to solve real life problems. Through this I understood that engineering is everything around us, contributing to building the world we live in today. Boats are able to move with just the sheer force of the wind on the sail and the keel, bridges are able to carry impressive weights
feedback_items.your_feedback: The first paragraph lists out these questions, then goes on about how you became interested in Formula One after watching cars, then fluid dynamics, then mechanical engineering, then engineering is around us, then boats do this, bridges do this. It's a little bit too summary. Is every single thing in there super valuable? Is everything resonating with you deeply? Is everything really academic? I personally think that could be two or three sentences and you need some more academic content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Condense this entire paragraph to 2-3 sentences. Bring in books, articles, maybe something more mathematical. For mechanical engineering, they want to see you're good at maths.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Through the subjects I studied, more specifically the notion of resultant forces such as lift and the stability of an object if it has low centers of mass and a wide base area, I was able to understand part of the Formula One cars design when it came to aerodynamics.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This Formula One stuff - the resultant forces, lift, stability of an object - it's a bit A level/IB level. That's fine if you then link it to something else that's a higher level. You're attempting to do that with the Tian Yu Lee paper, but none of it would make a tutor think 'wow, that's really impressive knowledge building.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you're keen on keeping this topic, push it up more. Go for something even higher level, even more developed. The whole section needs to go upwards a bit more in positioning.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was particularly struck by the way the rear wing creates 20 % of the downforce. With the design of the airfoil slightly angled, the air passing underneath flows much faster than that on top. In addition, according to Bernoulli's effect and the equation P + ½ ρv^^2 = constant
feedback_items.your_feedback: It's just because I've seen so many of these before that I'm now thinking it doesn't feel enough. This is a solid section, to be fair - nothing wrong with it, good general understanding. But because it's engineering, and just because it's so competitive, if you could bring in something even more, that would be great.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Bring in something beyond Bernoulli's effect - choose a less common topic or go significantly deeper to stand out from other applicants

feedback_items.weak_passage: Preparing for a French national logic Competition in which I finished in the top 1% , also helped me reinforce my critical and abstract thinking skills
feedback_items.your_feedback: This national logic competition - could you maybe have that included in your reference rather than here because it takes up space and it doesn't logically flow as well, because it's obviously critical thinking.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Move the French national logic competition to your reference

feedback_items.weak_passage: To widen my knowledge of the engineering field, I read 'Think like an engineer' which outlines the engineering mind-set while designing a product. It claims that it is a 'modular systems thinking' where multiple techniques and principals mix to understand the flow of life. While visiting the Google labs center in Paris... Furthermore, experiencing work experience at Thales and IDEMIA... This led me to read 'Where goods ideas come from: The natural history of innovation' by Steve Johnson.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole last section I felt like was too much of a list. You've got Think Like An Engineer (one sentence), then Google Labs centre, then IDEMIA, then FBI stuff, then Natural History of Innovation. There's just like a lot of things, but because it's got so many things in it, it's starting to read a little bit like a list. I wonder if you could go into a bit more detail into these things - that's how you reach higher level stuff.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Perhaps 2-3 points in there instead of 5+. Expand out each one more, link to engineering more clearly.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I followed the process of creation of a military surveillance radar as well as biometric systems of recognition used by the FBI, the Interpol and all main security systems -, I was struck by the importance of innovation. I was particularly fascinated by the constant change in products and small upgrades made on radars.
feedback_items.your_feedback: OK, that's great, you've observed it. It's really unnecessary to list out all of that (FBI, Interpol, all main security systems). Then you just say you were struck by the importance of innovation - not the best insight in the world. Fascinated by constant change and upgrades - it's kind of like, OK, you're fascinated by change and upgrades.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut the list of organizations. Replace 'struck by innovation' and 'fascinated by change' with more sophisticated technical insights from what you observed.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Is there any programming that you've done that you could talk about? Any larger projects that you've done? Any robotics things or anything where you've made something? I'm just wondering if you could maybe change the scope of what you're talking about entirely.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider adding: programming projects, larger engineering projects, robotics work, or anything you've built/made yourself

feedback_items.your_feedback: I can tell by your writing style, the things you've talked about, your logical flow that you are a smart person. I just don't think you're quite getting as much out of the personal statement as you probably could. Sorry to be vague, sorry to dishearten you - if you just left it as is, it will be absolutely fine. Oxford depends on the interview, Imperial depends on the interview, the other couple depend more on grades. But I think you could, if you've got the time, have another go at this.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: SUMMARY: First paragraph needs splitting down - include more current affairs, something recent, academic papers, books, lectures. Second section is solid but could be pushed up to avoid unfavourable comparison. Logic stuff to reference. Last paragraph far too listy - take 2-3 points, expand more, link to engineering better.
feedback_items.why_strong: Smart person with good writing style, logical flow, clearly capable of more
